messages.body:
Fog all over the frickin' place. Fog around Victoria Island, where the wealthy live behind razor wire. Fog in the streets of Lagos. Fog meandering down the Sagbama Expressway, scene of so many ghastly motor accidents, imaginary and otherwise. Fog curling around the houses sold while their owners are away. Fog up the Delta, where black gold is flared off into nothingness. And in the cybercafes, at the heart of the fog, sits a first-tier scammer who will never see the big money. But never has there been a fog so foul, dense and obscure, as the fog which pervades the following scambait.

Cast (in order of appearance):
 - the opener, cancer-victim Lad (mrs.nurning_r@yahoo.com)
 - a gentleman in difficulties
 - Doctor Lad, only mentioned
 - his ward
 - Global Security Lad (g.firmcompany@yahoo.co.uk, globalsy_64@yahoo.co.uk)

messages.body:
Dear Mrs. Rolland:
 
I'm sorry to hear of your suffering.  It seems to be something we have in common.  I myself have been diagnosed with Gullible's Disease.  It's a rare disorder that effects the neurotransmitters in the brain by producing an excessive amount of the hormone oxytocin.   This has a deleterious effect on my capacity to tell whether I should trust someone or not, and I tend to err on the side of trusting those whom I shouldn't.
 
As a result, I have lost a great deal of money and my ward, Ester Summerson, has taken over my financial dealings.  She may be said to possess the keys to the house.  She does a very good job in this capacity, and I rely upon her good judgement.
 
If you like, you can pass along your proposition to her.  Her e-mail is . 
 
Please feel free to forward our prior correspondence.
 
Thank you,
 
Tom Jarndyce
Bleak House
Surrey, UK

messages.body:
Dear Mr. Williams:
 
I would only suggest, then, that since you cannot arrange to deliver this shipment according to the very common practice of payment upon delivery, perhaps we ought to not bother going forward with this business.
 
I have received shipments from all over the world by this method and found it quite simple and effective.
 
It is only in the case of this particular transaction that I find resistance to the suggestion.  This raises many questions in my mind and I hope you'll forgive me, but I find myself rather backing away from the idea.
 
What is it you're up to, after all?
 
Summerson

messages.body:
Dear Mrs. Rolland:

The boxes were in England, and I was asked to pay some four thousand pounds to have them delivered, then I was asked to pay some two thousand pounds to have them delivered.  Now they are in Holland, and heaven only knows what sort of complications will arise.

You know my address.  Send the boxes if you like.  Hand deliver them.  Have your doctor carry them through the Chunnel on a bicycle. 

I have never been involved in so byzantine an exercise in my life.  Really!

My solicitors are in possession of all the documents concerning this business.  All of the e-mails are in their hands.  I shall wait until they make a determination as to what I ought to do.  

Summerson

messages.body:
Dear Mrs. Rolland:
 
Your previous agents, the Global Security Company, were informed that I do not pay for such things.  The arrangement I made with them, and will make with you, is this:  the objects in question will be shipped to my address in Kensington, London to be paid upon delivery.  I will inspect the items, and if they are what you claim them to be, you will be paid by negotiable securities via your messenger.
 
You see, Mrs, Rolland, I don't know you, and am hesitant to send money to people whom I don't know.  This is how my uncle, John Jarndyce, got his affairs into such a mess.  I have finally got them back in order and will not have them disarranged.
 
I have sent you the address.  The rest is up to you.
 
Summerson
